Our Workflow

The Art of Making Every Computation Count

Where it began

One of our cofounders, Kambiz, used to design chips for cellphones and consumer electronics. Back then, every transistor mattered. There was no room for waste. General-purpose processors were too power-hungry and too expensive. Clients‚Äîmajor tech and telecom companies‚Äîwould hand over a blueprint, and his job was to make it work with ruthless efficiency. Every decision was a tradeoff: precision versus accuracy, speed versus cost, complexity versus power consumption. This was not generic computing. It was optimization at the hardware level, tailored for specific applications.

Today the game has changed‚Äîbut the core principles haven‚Äôt.

Modern processors, especially NVIDIA‚Äôs, have evolved into highly flexible engines capable of running computations in anything from 8-bit to 64-bit floating-point precision. Not just fixed-point integers, but fully adaptable precision floating-point arithmetic. That flexibility unlocks enormous potential, not just in chip design but across industries‚Äîscientific computing, quantitative finance, and computer vision, to name a few.

And yet, most software is still written as if we‚Äôre stuck in the old days of fixed 64-bit precision.

That‚Äôs where Nippotica comes in. We bring the art of precision balancing‚Äîonce a necessity in chip design‚Äîinto the world of high-performance computing. By rewriting key parts of software to take advantage of adaptive precision, we make computation leaner, faster, and more efficient. The process is rigorous, but the results are worth it.

How Nippotica Makes Your Code Faster (Without Breaking Anything)

Most developers write code with one goal: make it work. At Nippotica, we take it a step further: make it work faster. And not just a little faster‚Äîwe optimize the math at its core so your software runs leaner, sharper, and more efficiently. The result? Fewer wasted computing cycles, lower cloud costs, and the same accuracy where it matters. Let‚Äôs face it‚Äîno one wants their code to be the reason the cloud bill gives the CFO indigestion.

Here‚Äôs how we do it.

Step 1: Can Your Code Be Optimized?

First, we take a hard look under the hood, at your source code‚ÄîPython, Matlab, R, Julia, it doesn‚Äôt matter. What matters is the math inside. If your code is already as efficient as it gets, we‚Äôll tell you. No vague promises. No unnecessary changes. But if there‚Äôs room for improvement, we move forward.

Step 2: Rewrite the Hotspots

Not all parts of your code are created equal. Some lines execute once and never again. Others are stuck in endless loops, running millions of times per second. Those hotspots are our focus. We rewrite them in C++, strip out inefficiencies, and set them up for adaptive precision.

Step 3: Adaptive Precision = Better Performance

Most developers default to double precision (FP64) because it‚Äôs the safe, easy choice. But easy isn‚Äôt always smart. Many algorithms don‚Äôt need that much precision. By carefully adjusting precision‚Äîusing FP32, FP16, or even FP8 where possible‚Äîwe free up processing power without sacrificing accuracy. In one case, switching to FP16 for a neural network inference task saved 30% in cloud costs without affecting model performance.

This isn‚Äôt about cutting corners. It‚Äôs about cutting waste.

Step 4: Stability Testing (a.k.a. No Surprises Later)

Before anything goes live, we stress-test the code to make sure it holds up. If it breaks? We tweak. If lowering precision creates instability? We adjust. The goal is to find the sweet spot where performance improves without affecting results.

Step 5: Deploy on High-Performance Hardware

Once we‚Äôve optimized the math, it‚Äôs time to put it to work‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs on AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, or an edge device like an NVIDIA Jetson Orin. The goal is always the same: maximize speed, minimize computational waste. Our team includes HPC engineers who‚Äôve worked on everything from weather simulations to computer vision algorithms.

Step 6: Monitor, Measure, and Keep It Running Smoothly

Optimization doesn‚Äôt stop at deployment. We monitor real-world performance, track execution times, and make adjustments if needed. If all goes well (and it usually does), your software is now running faster, smarter, and more efficiently than ever.

Why Nippotica‚Äôs Workflow Matters

Computing power isn‚Äôt cheap. And in industries like finance, AI, and engineering, speed is everything. At Nippotica, we don‚Äôt just make software run faster‚Äîwe make it smarter. Every floating-point operation is done at the right level of precision‚Äîno more, no less.

The result? The same accuracy, at a fraction of the computational cost.

Want to see what this looks like in action? Let‚Äôs talk and figure out how much performance you‚Äôve been leaving on the table.
